Description.val:
DESCRIPTION: This item funds modifications to C/KC-130 aircraft. The Lockheed C/KC-130 aircraft is a four engine, high-wing, all metal, long range, land based monoplane capable of all-weather transport of cargo or personnel and in-flight refueling. There are currently 98 aircraft in the Navy and Marine Corps inventory (55 active and 43 reserve). The expected Service Life is as follows:

T/M/S Service Date Service Life Expected Life
C-130T      10/91 - 11/95 450 mos.         2028-2032
KC-130T     04/84 - 02/96 450 mos.         2021-2033
KC-130J     09/00 - 10/26 450 mos.         2037-2063

Justification.val: Basis for FY2021 Budget request:  Provides funding to procure aircraft modifications to include Weapons Mission Kits, Electronic Countermeasures, Safety, Reliability, Readiness and Obsolescence Issues and Communication Navigation Surveillance System (CNS) Air Traffic Management (ATM) requirements such as Block Upgrade 8.1, and Avionics Obsolescence Upgrade (AOU) for the C/KC-130 program.

Name.@footnote: Increase in FY21 to support changes to KC-130J training devices as a result of Harvest Hawk Plus Integrated Mission Training Suite updates/requirements.

FY21 increase due to significant increase in NAVAIR Technical Area Expert (TAE) required assistance, increased VX-20 engineering support requirements, and additional VX-1 assessments to satisfy the increased OWS-430 validation/verification requirements. Specifically, these efforts require JAGM program assessment efforts; preparation/review of technical documentation, and review of applicable engineering change proposals (ECP) and technical directives (TDs).

Interim Contractor Support (ICS) covers the Original Equipment Manufacturer(OEM) HH+ support for completion of test.  FY21 ICS covers the HH+ & OEM JAGM support. FY22 ICS covers the HH+ & OEM JAGM Test Support. FY23 ICS covers the HH+ & OEM OWS-430 & JAGM production completion;30 MM Gun. FY24 ICS covers support for OEM 30 MM (Gun) NRE & test support planning. FY25 ICS covers 30 MM Cannon (Gun) Test execution.

Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: Weapon @ OWS430 A KIT
Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: JAGM A Kit
Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: 30MM Gun A - KIT

Name.val: 1.1.1) Harvest Hawk Plus A Kit - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: Harvest Hawk Plus A Kit

Name.@footnote: The completion of the ten A-Kit modifications from "Legacy" to "Plus" were planned for FY17 and 18.  HQMC did not want to sundown the Legacy Harvest HAWK capability until both VMGR-252 and 352 were fully functional with HH+.  HQMC directed that the final four (4) HH+ mods be completed in FY20 (Qty 3) and FY21 (Qty 1).  The budget exhibits were corrected to reflect this activity.

The OWS-430 NRE effort and test program has slipped by one (1) fiscal year (FY19 to FY20).  The original program plan was to procure three (3) A-Kits in FY20 which has been reduced to one (1) in FY20.  The single A-Kit procurement will address long lead for the first of three (3) installs in FY21. These costs were applied to NRE and Test efforts in FY20.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: Weapon @ OWS430 A KIT

Name.@footnote: The OWS-430 program execution has slid one (1) FY and has moved planned ECP activity to the right one (1) FY.  This impacted JAGM kit procurements, and moved one kit from FY20 to FY21.

ImplementationMethodName.val: Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: JAGM A Kit
Contractor Drive-In Mod:: Installation Name: 30MM Gun A - KIT

Name.@footnote: The OWS-430 NRE and test program has slipped one (1) fiscal (FY19 to FY20).  The original program plan was to procure three (3) B-Kits in FY20 which has been reduced to one (1) in FY20.  The single B-Kit procurement will address long lead for the first of three (3) installs in FY21. These costs were applied to NRE and Test efforts in FY20.
FY21 increase due to more extensive than planned aircraft instrumentation required to measure strain, flutter, and dynamics.

FY21 JAGM NRE of $6.483M required to integrate the new JAGM missile on the Harvest HAWK Plus (HH+) Aircraft configuration following OWS-430 modifications.  The OWS-430 modification allows captive carry and launch of this weapon and is a pre-requisite to integration, and requires the HH+ Mission Operator Pallet (MOP) software to be upgraded along with the Battle Management System (BMS) software.  This effort includes extensive code testing, lab integration and software builds prior to entry into government acceptance testing.
OWS-430 program execution delays have forced planned ECP activity to the right, moving planned JAGM testing activities from FY20 to FY22.

The OWS-430 modification program has slid to the right one (1) fiscal year and additional NRE is required to address the challenges associated with undefined NAVAIR Technical Area Expert (TAE) requirements, adding additional NRE requirements to FY20.

The OWS-430 modification program has slid to the right one (1) fiscal year.  As such, additional testing is required in FY20 to address the challenges associated with significantly increased test requirements with respect to wing loading, flutter, and flight dynamics.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: The KC-130 provides air-to-air refueling (AAR), aviation delivered ground refueling, tactical troop transport, aerial delivery of personnel and cargo, airborne radio relay, Digital Interoperability (DI), tactical aero-medical evacuation, Multi-Sensor Imagery and Reconnaissance (MIR), and Close Air Support (CAS). The objective of this effort is to integrate an MIR and air-to-ground weapons systems kit into the KC-130J aircraft to provide the Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) with an intra-theater CAS and MIR capability for real time intelligence gathering and target detection, identification, and tracking in support of weapons delivery and maintain the refueling capability and capacity of the KC-130J.  The MIR/Weapon System Kit will consist of a MIR pod, and wing mounted air-to-ground missiles and precision guided munitions. The system will be configured as a Roll-On/Roll-Off capability for rapid deployment. Future capabilities will support DI and include video and datalink connectivity, Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) communications, Hellfire P4/N4 compatibility, recovery of external fuel stores, and dual AAR systems, improved human factors, Joint Air to Ground Munitions (JAGM), small diameter bombs, and address obsolescence, test platform, and capability gaps.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: The KC-130J MIR/Weapons Mission Kit configuration provides MIR Weapon System Capability and CAS capability through both wing mounted munitions and Derringer Door mounted Standoff Precision Guided Munitions. The 6 baseline MIR/Weapons Mission Kits and 10 baseline aircraft modifications completed production in FY14. This Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program (OSIP) provides funding for HH+ to address obsolescence issues [update Battle Management System (BMS) for Hellfire P4/N4 variant missiles] and JAGM, human factors issues, and recover external fuel stores, and for OWS-430 to recover the dual AAR systems This OSIP also provides funding to address additional known fleet capability gaps such as tactical datalink, and communications.

Name.@footnote: 3.2: FY23 Training System funding supports implementing the AOU ECP to the 2F107 Operational Flight Trainer.

3.5: Other support includes lead systems integrator cost to assess and deliver AOU modification kits. FY21 increase includes Lead Systems Integration support for IOC and FRP activities; engineering effort to support integration and validation activities; airworthiness certification, and assessment results in support of CNS/ATM certification of critical operational issues affecting IOC.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: A Kits
[none specified]:: Installation Name: Installation Kits N/R

Name.@footnote: In July 2017, the United States Navy, Naval Reserve, and Marine Corps Reserve C/KC-130T aircraft were grounded as a result of a 54H60-111 propeller "Red Stripe".  The Red Stripe delayed the start of flight test for the Avionics Obsolescence Upgrade (AOU) program by 19 months, from Jul 2017 until Feb 2019, ultimately delaying Initial Operational Capability (IOC) by over two years.  To address schedule impacts in the year of execution and mitigate further delays in Developmental Test & Evaluation (DT) the FY 19-21 Full-Rate Production (FRP) kit quantities and installations were realigned.   There were 4 kits previously purchased prior to REDSTRIPE. Due to the REDSTRIPE, only 3 of the kits were installed due to fleet aircraft availability. The C-130T AOU team is ready to install the 4 kit which was procured prior to the REDSTRIPE immediately upon IOC.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: A Kits

Name.@footnote: 1.2.1: The NRE KIT for Prototype/Validation A/C QTY in previous budget request was erroneously omitted with dollar value accounted for.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: Installation Kits N/R

Name.@footnote: 2.2.1: NRE required thru FY21 for ground and flight assessment activities to support incorporation of the AOU modification on the KC-130T airframe.  NRE in FY22 is separate and distinct in which it funds integrations of C-130T AOU ECP on KC-130T Tanker A/C.

2.2.2: The FY20 mark reduced CTR efforts to correct identified issues during system checkout and validation, and also reduced the amount of testing planned. Funding in FY21 required for ground and flight operational assessment and validation/verification events that occur through 3QFY21 to support a 1QFY22 IOC.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: Objective of the Avionics/Obsolescence Upgrades (AOU) Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program (OSIP) is to preserve the world-wide capabilities of the C/KC-130 aircraft by providing required capability  enhancements and addressing obsolescence. The legacy C/KC-130T model aircraft have been in service for 28 years and still retain many of their original systems. AOU incorporates updated technologies to support safety, reliability, supportability, obsolescence, deficiency correction, mandated modifications, commonality, interoperability, and affordability of the C/KC-130T platform.  AOU updates apply to aircraft avionics, navigation, communications, transponders, sensors, transmitters, antennae, radars, and other electronic aircraft systems to meet global Communication, Navigation, and Surveillance/Air Traffic Management (CNS/ATM) requirements and provides necessary safety equipment for aircraft carrying troops.  AOU modifications will also be incorporated into existing training devices.  


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  AOU program is post Milestone-C, Low Rate Initial Production 2  approved. Government is Lead Systems Integrator, performing the majority of the NRE and installation of the validation and verification aircraft kits. Contract awarded for software integration non-recurring engineering and non-developmental systems in September 2012. Government ground testing on validation aircraft began 2017. Development Flight Test began February 2019 following a 19 month delay due to the K/C-130T Red Stripe that grounded most of the C/KC-130T fleet in September 2017. Validation aircraft will complete testing in FY21. Verification aircraft will undergo installation through 2020, followed by production installs beginning in 2022. Updated APB was signed by the MDA in Dec 2019.

In July 2017, the United States Navy, Naval Reserve, and Marine Corps Reserve C/KC-130T aircraft were grounded as a result of a 54H60-111 propeller "Red Stripe".  The Red Stripe delayed the start of flight test for the Avionics Obsolescence Upgrade (AOU) program by 19 months, from Jul 2017 until Feb 2019, ultimately delaying Initial Operational Capability (IOC) by over two years.  To address schedule impacts in the year of execution and mitigate further delays in Developmental Test & Evaluation (DT) the FY 19-21 Full-Rate Production (FRP) kit quantities and installations were realigned. The FY20 Congressional Mark of $3.085M limits the ability to correct deficiencies found in validation and extends efforts into 2021. As a result, procurement QTY adjusted to reflect this impact. 

Program of Record increase from OPNAV N98 from 20 to 25 aircraft.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified]:: Installation Name: LAIRCM JABS

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The KC-130 provides air-to-air refueling, rapid ground refueling, tactical troop transport, aerial delivery of personnel and cargo, airborne radio relay, Digital Interoperability (DI), tactical aero-medical evacuation, Multi-Sensor Imagery and Reconnaissance (MIR), and Close Air Support (CAS). This OSIP provides funding for the addition of new Aircraft Survivability Equipment (ASE), including Department of the Navy (DoN) Large Aircraft Infrared Counter Measures (LAIRCM) with Advanced Threat Warning (ATW) and the KC-130J Adjustable Ballast System (JABS) to the KC-130J Aircraft which will increase survivability and allow the aircraft to operate under expanded threat environments, thereby increasing combat effectiveness. The addition of DoN LAIRCM with the ATW sensor expands the aircraft's capability to perform its core Mission Essential Tasking in any infrared threat environment.  This OSIP also provides funding to ensure the most effective threat adaptive, reprogrammable, computer controlled threat defeating capabilities for the Defensive Electronic Counter Measures (DECM) portion of the ASE to increase combat effectiveness as well as future upgrades to the radar warning receiver (RWR) counter measure system.


DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The USMC is leveraging other DoN LAIRCM platforms to provide a common solution among naval platforms and to reduce Operations and Support (O&S) costs.  Modification of aircraft will be performed as a Drive-In Modification.

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: Technical Insertion provides for the incorporation and/or Tactical Demonstration (TACDEMO) of new or updated technologies to support safety, reliability, supportability, obsolescence, deficiency correction, mandated modifications, commonality, Digital Interoperability (DI), Electronic Warfare (EW), interoperability, C/KC-130 unique mission planning requirements, or affordability of the C/KC-130 platform as well as the necessary Reliability Centered Maintenance (RCM) baselining required for these efforts. Technical Insertion includes initial fielding of interactive Electronic Technical Manual (IETM) and Automated Logistic Environment (ALE) for production aircraft.  Technical Insertion updates support those technology initiatives that apply to aircraft avionics, navigation, communications,transponders, sensors, transmitters, antennae, mission computers and associated systems, electronic mission systems, C/KC-130 unique mission planning requirements or other electronic aircraft systems.  

Current modifications include: KC-130J Block Upgrade 8.1, which includes Communication Navigation Surveillance System (CNS) Air Traffic Management (ATM) mandates, new Flight Management System (FMS), transponder and Mission Computer updates for Required Navigation Performance (RNP) and Area Navigation (RNAV) and Automatic Dependent Surveillance - Broadcast (ADS-B) Out, safety improvements Improved Intercom System (ICS) Portable Audio (PA) System and enhanced covert lighting, deficiency correction Telecommunications Electronics Material Protected from Emanating Spurious Transmissions (TEMPEST) compliance, and DI updates (Mode 5 Identification Friend and Foe (IFF) and Link 16). Unique C/KC-130 mission planning requirement CAT 5.0 and Flight Performance Model (FPM) Take-off and Landing Data (TOLD) certification. 

Planned future modifications: Capability Management Upgrade (CMU) with Flight Management System (FMS) performance enhancements to ensure future mission readiness of the KC-130J fleet, Software Reprogrammable Payload (SRP), the Blue Force Tracker (BFT), Blue Force Situational Awareness (BFSA) initiative, and Ku Band Satellite System (Kuss) Beyond Line of Sight (BLOS) to support DI within the Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) and across the services. Unique C/KC-130 mission planning requirements including map and communication tools. Development of tablet enabled applications such as Electronic Take-off and Landing Data (ETOLD), Weight and Balance (W&B), and FPM planning.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: Block 8.1 upgrade consists of 57 kits and installs starting in FY18 and completing beyond the FYDP.

Name.@footnote: The T56 Series 3.5 Engine Upgrade Program provides improvement in performance with design enhancements including with new compressor wheels and compressor and turbine blades and vanes. Performance benefits include: Improved fuel efficiency, increased reliability, increased take-off thrust, increased climb rate, decreased take-off field length, increased payload carriage, and increased range.  The program modifies 140 T56 Series 3 engines in the USNR fleet to the Series 3.5 configuration within 5 years to maximize the return of investment for the Navy.  There will be a 24 month lead time in Kit procurement with procurements beginning in FY 22 and depot installations beginning in FY24.
Center Wing Box should be funded with 1A5A. A line was put in the exhibit in order to balance to control; issue sheet will be submitted with budget.

Name.val: 2.1.2) KC-130J Observer Seat B Kit - Organic

Description.val:
DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION: This line item funds modifications to Navy C/KC-130 aircraft. To ensure preservation of Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Assault Support and Navy-Unique Fleet Essential Aircraft capabilities world-wide, this Safety, Reliability, Readiness and Obsolescence Improvement OSIP provides funding for issues that adversely affect aircraft safety, reliability and/or availability. Applicable areas include Power and Propulsion, Airframes and Structures, Safety and Life Support, Electrical Power, Readiness Initiatives and Survivability.  This OSIP provides resources to correct such issues via Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) and other applicable efforts by modifying, improving, and upgrading aircraft structural safety and reliability.  Modifications include:  Airframe Structural Upgrades such as Flight Controls Surfaces, Forward Fuselage, Aft Fuselage, Inner/Outer Wing, Critical Structures; and Aircraft Subsystem Upgrades, such as Electrical, Hydraulic, Environmental Control Systems (ECS), Fuel, Launch and Recovery, Critical Structures, Mechanical, Secondary Power, and Fire Suppression Systems.

The T56 Series 3.5 Engine Upgrade Program provides improvement in performance with design enhancements including with new compressor wheels and compressor and turbine blades and vanes. Performance benefits include: Improved fuel efficiency, increased reliability, increased take-off thrust, increased climb rate,decreased take-off field length, increased payload carriage, and increased range.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  The current KC-130 aircraft do not have crashworthy observer seats in the cargo compartment required for safe operations in the tactical environment. The observer seats will provide increased crash attenuation, mission endurance, and restraint systems. The observer seats are Commercial Off The Shelf (COTS) items and are currently being installed in USAF C-130 Aircraft. Planned material solution is being updated to better meet USMC requirements. Current Inter-Communication System (ICS) system is a hardwire solution that impedes the aircrews' ability to carry out critical mission sets. A wireless ICS system will provide safer, unrestricted mobility for crew members to perform critical missions such as Aerial Cargo Delivery, ground and in-flight refueling. In addition, a wireless ICS facilitates crew members egress in the event of an emergency. The legacy 3,600 gallon fuel tanks in the cargo compartment need to be modified to fit the KC-130J due to obsolete components that are not compatible with the new KC-130J. Planned Engineering Change Proposals (ECP) for reliability are carbon brakes, corrosion control, and engine upgrades. Additionally, night vision goggles are being upgraded to white phosphorous as a safety improvement to the degraded visual environment.
